p.s: Description of Mycobacterium alvei sp. nov.
Mycobacterium alvei (al've.i. L.gen.n.alvei, bed of a river, referring to the place where this species was first isolated)
The cells of M. alvei are short rods that are 1 to 3 μm long and 0.5 to 0.7 μm wide; they are mainly strongly acid fast, except for a small number (less than 10%) of cyanophil forms.
The cells are gram-positive rods and frequently appear to be coccoid.
Smears prepared from Youmans medium (without Tween 80) and Middlebrook 7H12 medium contain clumps of rods but not cords.
Colonies on Löwenstein-Jensen medium and on Middlebrook 7H10 agar are eugonic, rough, and nonpigmented in the dark and also after exposure to light.
Growth occurs within 5 days at 30"C, the optimum growth temperature.
At 37°C, the organisms grow more slowly (growth appears within 10 to 15 days), and they do not grow at 45 or 52°C.
The type strain produces thermostable catalase and is positive for arylsulfatase (3 days), nitrate reductase, urease, β-glucosidase, and β-galactosidase.
No growth occurs in MacConkey agar without crystal violet.
Salicylate is not degraded to catechol.
Niacin is not produced.
Iron uptake is negative.
Growth is inhibited in the presence of sodium chloride (5%) and picric acid (0.2%).
Inositol, mannitol, and sodium citrate are not utilized as sole carbon sources.
Acid is produced from glucose, fructose, and trehalose but not from dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, rhamnose, and xylose.

The type strain is resistant to D-cycloserine, streptomycin, isoniazid (0.1 and 1 mg/liter), rifampin, p-aminosalicylic acid, and thiacetazone and is susceptible to isoniazid (10 mg/liter), kanamycin, and capreomycin.
Gas chromatography of the total fatty acid methyl esters reveals the presence of tuberculostearate.
Pyrolytic C2-C3 cleavage gives intense peaks corresponding to docosanoate and tetracosanoate, indicating that characteristic α-branched, β-hydroxylated mycobacterial mycolates are present.
Secondary alcohols are not detected.
As determined by TLC, M. alvei contains α-mycolates and ω-1 methoxymycolates.

Since as determined by gas chromatography M. alvei produces lipid profiles similar to those of the other rapidly growing nonphotochromogenic mycobacteria (18, 20, 25,45), analysis of the mycolic acid pattern allows a clear distinction between M. alvei and the previously described Mycobactenum species.

Recently, we have found that M. porcinum, M. senegalense, and some strains of M. fortuitum and "Mycobactenum peregrinum" also contain appreciable amounts of 0-1 methoxymycolate, but in these species this mycolate is always accompanied by an epoxymycolate (Table 3) (26,27,31).
However, in M. alvei the ω-1 methoxymycolate is the only oxygenated compound (28).
